item.title: Word of the Day: commiserate
item.description: This word has appeared in 43 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: How Much Longer Can Mexico Walk Trump’s Tightrope?
item.description: Trump wants total war on Mexico’s cartels. Sheinbaum won’t give it to him.
item.dc:creator: Mary Beth Sheridan

media:content.media:credit: Guillermo Arias/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Qué es el ‘neomonarquismo’ y qué dice de Trump
item.description: Los expertos intentan vislumbrar el enfoque del presidente de EE. UU. sobre la política global y la economía. Una teoría ve antecedentes en un gobierno dinástico.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El príncipe heredero Mohammed bin Salman dio al presidente Trump una cálida y opulenta bienvenida en Arabia Saudita el año pasado.

item.title: Academias, éxito y felicidad: el debate que atraviesa a Corea del Sur
item.description: La competencia escolar alcanza niveles tan altos que niños muy pequeños asisten a clases privadas, una tendencia que ha encendido alarmas sobre el bienestar infantil.
item.dc:creator: Max Kim and Jean Chung

media:content.media:description: Una escena habitual en Seúl: madres que cargan las mochilas de sus hijos tras recogerlos de las clases nocturnas en hagwons.

item.title: La reina Máxima de Holanda se alista en el ejército
item.description: La reina Máxima se enroló como reservista, dijo la Casa Real, dado que la seguridad del país “ya no puede darse por sentada”.
item.dc:creator: Koba Ryckewaert

media:content.media:credit: Ministerio de Defensa de los Países Bajos.
media:content.media:description: Fotografía difundida por la Casa Real que muestra a la reina Máxima de Holanda durante un entrenamiento militar en Breda el miércoles.

item.title: Por qué una de las causas del descenso de la natalidad puede ser la prosperidad
item.description: El crecimiento económico tiene el efecto secundario no deseado de hacer más difícil y cara la crianza.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub

media:content.media:credit: Cris Bouroncle/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Mujeres en una protesta en Lima, Perú, en 2022, con trajes inspirados en los personajes de la novela y serie de televisión El cuento de la criada.

item.title: Residents of Cortina, a Winter Olympics Hub, Are Angry About All the Construction
item.description: In Cortina d’Ampezzo, a hub for the Games in northern Italy, some residents, including a former Olympian, are annoyed about all the construction. Others are annoyed that they’re annoyed.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Josephine de La Bruyère

media:content.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Laborers in Cortina d’Ampezzo working in January to finish a ski lift before the Winter Games begin.

item.title: ‘My Crazy Friend’: The Royals Who Stayed Close to Epstein
item.description: Emails, texts, photos and videos show how Jeffrey Epstein, even after becoming a convicted sex offender, burnished his ties to royal family members from several countries and their advisers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear

media:content.media:credit: Lise Aserud/NTB, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Crown Princess Mette-Marit of Norway at an event in Oslo in 2024.

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 5, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Feb. 5, 2026.

item.title: Rethinking Shakespeare in Shanghai
item.description: A recent production of “Othello” proves that small creative flowers can grow between the dreary slabs of cultural concrete laid by the Communist Party.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Gilles Sabrié

media:content.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times

item.title: Files Reveal Epstein’s Money Mingled with Silicon Valley’s Tech Start-Ups
item.description: The disgraced financier regularly courted tech industry figures not just for their prestige but also for access to promising companies.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Erin Griffith and Matthew Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Department of Justice, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Last week’s disclosures of Jeffrey Epstein’s communications offer insight into how he made his money as an investor after his 2008 conviction.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Wonder Drug Keeps Sports In Its Clutches
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 5, 2025.

item.title: El largo adiós de la autodeportación: una pareja de California vuelve a México
item.description: Enrique Castillejos y su esposa, María Elena Hernandez, formaron y criaron una familia en California. Pero, como migrantes indocumentados, decidieron volver a México en lugar de vivir con miedo a las redadas del gobierno de Trump.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquín and Gabriela Bhaskar

media:content.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times

item.title: Savannah Guthrie and Siblings Plead for Mother’s Release
item.description: Savannah Guthrie, co-host of NBC’s “Today” show, and her siblings, Annie and Camron, posted a video saying they would consider a ransom deal for their missing mother, but that they would need proof that she is alive. Their 84-year-old mother, Nancy, was last seen at her home near Tucson, Ariz., on Saturday.

item.title: Venezuela Said to Detain Maduro Allies Targeted by the U.S.
item.description: The questioning of the politically connected businessmen, Raúl Gorrín and Alex Saab, signaled deepening cooperation between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Annie Correal

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 5, 2026
item.description: Dario Salvucci makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Savannah Guthrie Addresses Mother’s Abductor: ‘We Are Ready to Talk’
item.description: Ms. Guthrie, the television anchor, and her siblings released a video on Wednesday night asking for proof that their mother, Nancy, is alive.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Reis Thebault

item.title: Brad Karp Resigns as Paul Weiss Chairman Amid Epstein Fallout
item.description: The decision followed the release of a series of embarrassing emails between Mr. Karp and Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein, Michael S. Schmidt and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

media:content.media:credit: Carly Zavala for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “Recent reporting has created a distraction and has placed a focus on me that is not in the best interests of the firm,” Brad Karp said in a statement from Paul Weiss.

item.title: The Long Goodbye: A California Couple Self-Deports to Mexico
item.description: Enrique Castillejos and his wife, Maria Elena Hernandez, raised a family in California. But they were undocumented immigrants, and after President Trump’s crackdown began, they decided to return to Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquín and Gabriela Bhaskar

media:content.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times

item.title: China’s Xi Presses Trump on Taiwan in Phone Call
item.description: Both leaders gave versions of what they discussed, but the Chinese president’s take made clear the issue of the island was front and center.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green

media:content.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump and President Xi Jinping of China in South Korea in October.

item.title: Man Who Falsely Claimed He Killed Charlie Kirk Is Sentenced to Prison
item.description: The authorities said the man, George Zinn, tried to derail their search for Mr. Kirk’s actual killer. He faces up to 15 years in prison on obstruction of justice and other charges.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler

media:content.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A man who falsely claimed to have killed the conservative activist Charlie Kirk faces up to 15 years in prison after pleading no contest to a felony charge of obstruction of justice.

item.title: U.S. and Iran to Hold Talks in Oman on Friday
item.description: The White House confirmed a meeting would take place after days of conflicting reports on the talks’ timing, location and format.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

media:content.media:credit: Burak Kara/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, was expected to meet with U.S. envoys in Oman on Friday.

item.title: New York City Partners with W.H.O. as U.S. Withdraws From Global Effort
item.description: City health authorities are joining a network that counters new pathogens and emerging outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein

media:content.media:credit: Robert Hradil/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Trump administration withdrew the United States from the World Health Organization in January.

item.title: Canada’s Tate McRae Roots for Team USA in New Olympics Ad
item.description: Tate McRae’s promotional video for NBC, in which she name checks Team USA athletes, has drawn the ire of some Canadians as the country’s relationship with the United States hits new lows.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

media:content.media:credit: Monica Schipper/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Tate McRae in December in Los Angeles.

item.title: Trump Says His Unpredictable Style Gives Him Leverage. But It Has a Cost.
item.description: A year into President Trump’s second term, his threats, retreats, twists and turns appear to be wearing on allies and adversaries.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump on Tuesday. White House officials say his negotiating style has yielded results, pointing to new trade deals and peace deals.

item.title: Newsom, Shapiro and Other Democrats Whip Up the 2028 Book Buzz
item.description: A number of potential presidential candidates are releasing memoirs as the shadow primary heats up.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Evan Agostini/Invision, via Associated Press; Karsten Moran for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania and Gov. Gavin Newsom of California are both promoting books.

item.title: The Washington Post despide a más de 300 periodistas
item.description: Los despidos afectarán la cobertura local, internacional y deportiva del Post, y reducirán el número de todos sus empleados en un 30 por ciento.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Katie Robertson and Erik Wemple

media:content.media:credit: Annabelle Gordon/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Matt Murray, executive editor of The Washington Post, told employees that the revamped paper would focus more on national news and politics, and business and health, and less on other areas.

item.title: Senators Accuse Equifax of ‘Price-Gouging’ Medicaid Programs
item.description: The company’s data will be essential for many states to comply with new work requirements for the health insurance program that take effect next year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff, Margot Sanger-Katz and Asmaa Elkeurti

media:content.media:credit: Tami Chappell/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Many states rely on an Equifax product to verify Medicaid applicants’ wages and work hours.

item.title: I’m the Prime Minister of Spain. This Is Why the West Needs Migrants.
item.description: In Spain, it is our duty to become the welcoming and tolerant society our ancestors would have hoped to find on the other side of our borders.

item.title: University of Southern California Names a Lawyer, Beong-Soo Kim, as Its New President
item.description: The president, Beong-Soo Kim, had served on an interim basis and already faced pressure from the Trump administration to join a higher education compact to follow a set of conservative ideas. He refused.
item.dc:creator: Mark Arsenault

media:content.media:credit: Juliana Yamada/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Beong-Soo Kim previously served the school as senior vice president and general counsel and was a lecturer at the U.S.C. Gould School of Law.

item.title: Dutch Queen Joins the Military
item.description: Queen Máxima of the Netherlands enlisted as a reservist, the Royal House said, because the country’s security “can no longer be taken for granted.”
item.dc:creator: Koba Ryckewaert

media:content.media:credit: Dutch Ministry of Defense
media:content.media:description: A photograph released by the Royal House showing Queen Máxima of the Netherlands during military training in Breda on Wednesday.

item.title: Jersey City Faces a Stunning Budget Deficit, Report Shows
item.description: The city’s new mayor, James Solomon, is blaming his predecessor, Steven Fulop, who just became the head of an influential business advocacy group in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor James Solomon of Jersey City said on Wednesday that the city’s budget deficit amounts to $255 million, more than it spends annually on police and fire services.

item.title: Ryan Murphy’s ‘Love Story’ Premiere Embraced ’90s New York
item.description: A party for Ryan Murphy’s new TV show about the couple drew a crowd that included Naomi Watts, Martha Stewart and Grace Gummer.

item.title: Blanche Marvin, 100, Dies; Critic Was, Maybe, ‘Streetcar’ Inspiration
item.description: She was a ubiquitous presence at London theaters and claimed to have inspired the name — and final words — of Tennessee Williams’s Blanche DuBois.

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Mistook Her Optimism for an Act’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

item.title: Doctors’ Group Endorses Restrictions on Gender-Related Surgery for Minors
item.description: The A.M.A.’s announcement followed a similar recommendation from the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Other medical groups argued for a more personalized approach.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.category: World Professional Association for Transgender Health

media:content.media:credit: Jim West/Alamy
media:content.media:description: Two major medical organizations have now endorsed age limits on gender-related surgery for teenagers struggling with gender dysphoria.

item.title: The Washington Post Eliminates Its Sports Department
item.description: The Post is laying off or reassigning all the reporters and editors in its sports section, days before the Super Bowl and the Winter Olympics in Italy.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin

media:content.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Washington Post leadership announced major layoffs within the newsroom.

item.title: Google Plans to Double Spending Amid A.I. Race
item.description: Profits jumped 30 percent to $34.5 billion last quarter, and the tech giant is increasing its capital spending this year to as much as $185 billion.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle

media:content.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A Google ad in Times Square.

item.title: Ucrania considera ceder territorio para lograr la paz
item.description: Las encuestas muestran una creciente aceptación de las concesiones territoriales entre un público cansado de la guerra, siempre y cuando Ucrania reciba garantías de seguridad sólidas.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova

media:content.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El destino de la región de Donbás es uno de los temas más controvertidos de las conversaciones de paz.

item.title: In Forcing the Clintons to Testify on Epstein, Comer Sets a New Precedent
item.description: The Republican chairman’s successful targeting of a former president who faces no charge of wrongdoing was the sort of tactic typical in an autocracy where leaders fear being jailed when they are out of power.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative James R. Comer of Kentucky, at the Capitol on Tuesday, had been trying for months to get Bill and Hillary Clinton to testify in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

item.title: El gobierno de Trump retira a 700 agentes de inmigracion de Mineápolis
item.description: Unos 2000 agentes y parte del personal se quedarán en la ciudad, donde las muertes a manos de agentes federales de dos personas que protestaban contra la represión migratoria han generado indignación.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tom Homan, zar fronterizo de la Casa Blanca, en una conferencia de prensa en Mineápolis el miércoles.

item.title: Is Emily Brontë’s ‘Wuthering Heights’ Actually the Greatest Love Story of All Time?
item.description: Catherine and Heathcliff are returning to the screen, but their passion burns brightest in a handful of sentences from Emily Brontë’s novel.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott

item.title: Babies, Robots and Climate Change
item.description: It’s often assumed that lower birthrates could help slow climate change and A.I. disruption. The reality is more complex.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times

item.title: Juegos Olímpicos de Invierno: esta vez habrá 4 desfiles
item.description: Como los Juegos de Invierno de 2026 estarán tan dispersos geográficamente, los atletas desfilarán en Milán y en varias sedes más.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather

media:content.media:credit: Daniele Mascolo/Reuters
media:content.media:description: En la ceremonia de inauguración, los atletas participarán en el tradicional Desfile de las Naciones en el estadio de San Siro de Milán.

item.title: New York and New Jersey Resolve Fight Over Port Authority Control
item.description: The board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will vote this week to confirm Kathryn Garcia as the executive director and Jean Roehrenbeck as the deputy executive director of the agency.
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGeehan
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey

media:content.media:credit: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times; James Estrin/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: New York Governor Kathy Hochul and New Jersey Governor Mikie Sherrill each nominated an executive director to lead the Port Authority.

item.title: How A.I. Is Reshaping Our World: A Live Webinar for Students on March 4
item.description: Hear from journalists who are covering how this technology is changing life in and out of school. Teachers should submit students’ video questions using the form below.
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Trump’s Border Czar to Pull 700 Agents Out of Minnesota
item.description: Tom Homan, the White House border czar, said that 700 immigration agents will be moved out of Minnesota. About 2,000 agents and officers will stay behind to enforce the administration’s immigration crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Mitssunaga

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tom Homan, the White House border czar, at a news conference in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: Fulton County in Georgia Demands Return of 2020 Election Materials
item.description: Fulton County, Ga., filed a motion on Wednesday demanding the return of ballots and other election materials that were seized by the F.B.I.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: F.B.I. agents searched an election center in Fulton County, Ga., last week and seized ballots and other election materials.
